The agreement involves the Nuclear Power Corporation of India Limited (NPCIL) and the Emirates Nuclear Energy Corporation (ENEC). The primary objective of this MoU is to enhance cooperation in the peaceful use of nuclear energy. This includes collaboration in the operation and maintenance of nuclear power plants, sourcing of nuclear goods and services from India, and exploring mutual investment opportunities. The agreement also aims to create a framework for sharing knowledge and expertise in all areas of nuclear energy development. The UAE has been investing heavily in nuclear energy as part of its strategy to diversify its energy sources. The Barakah Nuclear Power Plant, operated by ENEC, is the first nuclear power plant in the Arab world. It consists of four APR-1400 nuclear reactors, with a total capacity of 5,600 megawatts (MW). The plant is expected to provide up to 25% of the UAE’s electricity needs once fully operational. The first unit of the Barakah plant began commercial operations in April 2021, and the remaining units are expected to be operational by 2025. India, on the other hand, has a well-established nuclear energy program. The country operates 22 nuclear reactors with a total installed capacity of 6,780 MW. The Indian government has set an ambitious target to increase this capacity to 22,480 MW by 2031. The NPCIL, which is responsible for the design, construction, and operation of nuclear power plants in India, plays a crucial role in achieving this target. The MoU between NPCIL and ENEC is expected to facilitate the exchange of technical expertise and best practices in nuclear energy. This collaboration will not only strengthen the nuclear energy capabilities of both countries but also contribute to global efforts to promote the peaceful use of nuclear energy. The signing of the MoU is a testament to the growing strategic partnership between India and the UAE. Over the past few years, the two countries have significantly expanded their cooperation in various fields, including trade, investment, defense, and energy. The UAE is India’s third-largest trading partner, with bilateral trade reaching $59 billion in 2023. The UAE is also one of the largest investors in India, with cumulative investments of over $15 billion. In addition to the MoU on civil nuclear cooperation, India and the UAE have also signed agreements in other areas during the Crown Prince’s visit. These include a long-term agreement for the supply of liquefied natural gas (LNG) from the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company (ADNOC) to Indian Oil Corporation Limited (IOCL). The agreement envisages the supply of one million metric tonnes per annum (MMTPA) of LNG from ADNOC’s lower-carbon Ruwais gas project. This is the third such contract signed by India in a little more than a year to strengthen its energy security. IOCL and GAIL earlier signed long-term agreements for 1.2 MMTPA and 0.5 MMTPA, respectively, with ADNOC. Another significant agreement signed during the visit is between the Government of Gujarat and the Abu Dhabi Developmental Holding Company PJSC (ADQ) for the development of food parks in India. This agreement is part of the I2U2 initiative, which includes India, Israel, the UAE, and the United States. The initiative aims to promote joint investments in various sectors, including food security, water, energy, and health. The MoU on civil nuclear cooperation is expected to have far-reaching implications for both India and the UAE. For India, the agreement provides an opportunity to leverage its expertise in nuclear energy to enhance its strategic partnership with the UAE. It also opens up new avenues for Indian companies to participate in the UAE’s nuclear energy program. For the UAE, the agreement is a step towards achieving its goal of becoming a global leader in nuclear energy. It also underscores the UAE’s commitment to diversifying its energy sources and reducing its dependence on fossil fuels. The MoU is also significant in the context of global efforts to combat climate change. Nuclear energy is considered a low-carbon energy source, and its increased use can help reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The collaboration between India and the UAE in the field of nuclear energy is expected to contribute to global efforts to promote sustainable and clean energy. In conclusion, the signing of the MoU for civil nuclear cooperation between India and the UAE is a landmark development in the bilateral relations between the two countries. It reflects the growing strategic partnership between India and the UAE and their commitment to promoting the peaceful use of nuclear energy. The agreement is expected to enhance cooperation in the operation and maintenance of nuclear power plants, sourcing of nuclear goods and services, and exploring mutual investment opportunities. It also underscores the importance of nuclear energy in achieving energy security and combating climate change. As India and the UAE continue to strengthen their strategic partnership, the MoU on civil nuclear cooperation is expected to play a crucial role in shaping the future of their bilateral relations.

On August 29, 2024, Australia and Indonesia signed a landmark Defense Cooperation Treaty, marking a significant milestone in their bilateral relations. The treaty was signed by Australia’s Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence, Richard Marles, and Indonesia’s President-elect and Minister of Defence, Prabowo Subianto, at a ceremony held in Magelang, Central Java province. This agreement is seen as the most significant defense pact between the two nations to date. The primary objective of the treaty is to enhance practical cooperation and interoperability between the Australian Defence Force (ADF) and the Indonesian National Armed Forces (TNI). This includes joint exercises, personnel exchanges, and technical cooperation in areas such as maritime security, counter-terrorism, humanitarian assistance, disaster relief, logistics support, and defense industry collaboration. The treaty also provides enhanced legal protections for military personnel operating in each other’s countries. One of the key components of the treaty is the establishment of a framework for joint military exercises. The first of these exercises, named “Chris Woomera,” is scheduled to take place in Surabaya in November 2024. This exercise will involve 2,000 personnel from both the ADF and TNI, making it the largest bilateral military exercise ever conducted between the two countries. The exercise will cover air, land, and sea operations, and is expected to significantly enhance the interoperability of the two forces. In addition to joint exercises, the treaty facilitates the exchange of military personnel for education and training purposes. This will allow officers and soldiers from both countries to gain valuable experience and knowledge by training in each other’s military academies and institutions. The agreement also includes provisions for technical cooperation in areas such as science and technology, which will enable both countries to share advancements and innovations in defense technology. The signing of the treaty comes at a time when both Australia and Indonesia are seeking to strengthen their defense capabilities in response to regional security challenges. The Indo-Pacific region has seen increasing geopolitical tensions in recent years, with issues such as territorial disputes in the South China Sea and the rise of non-state actors posing significant threats to regional stability. By enhancing their defense cooperation, Australia and Indonesia aim to contribute to a more secure and stable Indo-Pacific region. The economic aspect of the treaty is also noteworthy. The defense industry collaboration component of the agreement is expected to open up new opportunities for defense contractors and manufacturers in both countries. Australian defense companies will have the chance to participate in Indonesia’s defense procurement programs, while Indonesian companies will be able to access the Australian defense market. This is expected to boost the defense industries of both nations and create new jobs and economic opportunities. The treaty also underscores the importance of maritime security in the bilateral relationship. Both Australia and Indonesia have extensive coastlines and rely heavily on maritime trade for their economic prosperity. The agreement includes provisions for joint maritime patrols and cooperation in combating maritime threats such as piracy, illegal fishing, and smuggling. This is expected to enhance the security of vital sea lanes and contribute to the overall stability of the region. In the context of counter-terrorism, the treaty provides a framework for enhanced cooperation in intelligence sharing, joint operations, and capacity building. Both countries have faced significant challenges from terrorist groups in recent years, and the agreement aims to strengthen their ability to respond to these threats. By working together, Australia and Indonesia hope to improve their counter-terrorism capabilities and contribute to global efforts to combat terrorism. Humanitarian assistance and disaster relief are also key components of the treaty. The Indo-Pacific region is prone to natural disasters such as earthquakes, tsunamis, and cyclones, and both Australia and Indonesia have extensive experience in disaster response. The agreement includes provisions for joint training and exercises in disaster response, as well as the establishment of mechanisms for rapid deployment of personnel and resources in the event of a disaster. This is expected to enhance the ability of both countries to respond effectively to natural disasters and provide timely assistance to affected communities. The signing of the Defense Cooperation Treaty is a testament to the strong and growing relationship between Australia and Indonesia. Over the past few years, the two countries have significantly expanded their cooperation in various fields, including trade, investment, education, and cultural exchange. The defense treaty is expected to further strengthen this relationship and contribute to the overall stability and prosperity of the Indo-Pacific region. In addition to the defense treaty, Australia and Indonesia have also signed several other agreements aimed at enhancing their bilateral cooperation. These include a revised and upgraded version of the Australia-Indonesia Defense Cooperation Arrangement, which was originally signed in February 2018. The updated arrangement includes new provisions for counter-terrorism and cybersecurity cooperation, reflecting the evolving security challenges faced by both countries. The economic ties between Australia and Indonesia are also strong. Indonesia is Australia’s 13th largest trading partner, with bilateral trade reaching $17.8 billion in 2023. The two countries have also signed a Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA), which aims to boost trade and investment by reducing tariffs and other barriers. The CEPA is expected to create new opportunities for businesses in both countries and contribute to economic growth and development. The signing of the Defense Cooperation Treaty is expected to have far-reaching implications for both Australia and Indonesia. For Australia, the agreement provides an opportunity to enhance its strategic partnership with Indonesia and strengthen its presence in the Indo-Pacific region. It also underscores Australia’s commitment to working with its regional partners to promote peace, security, and stability. For Indonesia, the treaty represents a significant step towards enhancing its defense capabilities and addressing regional security challenges. It also reflects Indonesia’s commitment to playing a more active role in regional security and contributing to the stability of the Indo-Pacific region. In conclusion, the signing of the Defense Cooperation Treaty between Australia and Indonesia is a landmark development in the bilateral relationship between the two countries. The treaty is expected to enhance practical cooperation and interoperability between the Australian Defence Force and the Indonesian National Armed Forces, and contribute to regional security and stability. It also underscores the importance of defense cooperation in addressing the evolving security challenges faced by both countries. As Australia and Indonesia continue to strengthen their strategic partnership, the Defense Cooperation Treaty is expected to play a crucial role in shaping the future of their bilateral relations.

The Henley Passport Index for 2024 has been released, providing a comprehensive ranking of the world’s passports based on the number of destinations their holders can access without a prior visa. This index, compiled by Henley & Partners, uses exclusive data from the International Air Transport Association (IATA) and is widely regarded as the authoritative source for global passport rankings. In 2024, the Henley Passport Index ranks 199 different passports against 227 travel destinations. The index is updated monthly, reflecting the dynamic nature of global mobility. The rankings are determined by the number of destinations a passport holder can visit without needing a visa, or where they can obtain a visa on arrival, a visitor’s permit, or an electronic travel authority (ETA). At the top of the 2024 rankings is Singapore, whose passport holders can access 195 destinations without a prior visa. This marks a significant achievement for Singapore, which has consistently ranked highly in the index. Following closely behind are several European countries, including Germany, Italy, and Spain, each with a visa-free score of 192. Japan, which held the top spot for several years, now shares the second position with these European nations. The third position is occupied by a group of countries, including Austria, Finland, Ireland, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, South Korea, and Sweden, each with a visa-free score of 191. These countries have maintained strong global mobility, allowing their citizens to travel freely to a large number of destinations. Australia and New Zealand are also prominent in the rankings, with Australia holding the fifth position with a score of 189 and New Zealand in the fourth position with a score of 190. The United Kingdom, which has seen fluctuations in its ranking over the years, is currently in the fourth position alongside New Zealand. The United States, once a dominant force in global mobility, has seen a decline in its ranking. In 2024, the U.S. passport holds the eighth position with a visa-free score of 186. This decline reflects the increasing restrictions and complexities in global travel, as well as the evolving geopolitical landscape. India, with its vast population and growing global influence, holds the 85th position in the 2024 Henley Passport Index. Indian passport holders can access 59 destinations without a prior visa. This is a slight improvement from previous years, reflecting India’s efforts to enhance its global mobility and strengthen diplomatic ties. The Henley Passport Index also highlights the disparities in global mobility. Countries like Afghanistan, Iraq, and Syria are at the bottom of the rankings, with their passport holders having access to fewer than 30 destinations without a prior visa. This stark contrast underscores the challenges faced by citizens of these countries in terms of global mobility and access to opportunities. The index not only serves as a tool for individuals to assess the strength of their passports but also provides valuable insights for policymakers and governments. It highlights the importance of diplomatic relations, visa agreements, and international cooperation in enhancing global mobility. For instance, countries that have signed multiple visa waiver agreements tend to rank higher in the index. The Henley Passport Index has been tracking global mobility trends for nearly two decades. Since its inception in 2005, the index has provided a unique perspective on the changing dynamics of global travel. Over the years, the average number of destinations that travelers can access visa-free has nearly doubled, from 58 in 2006 to 111 in 2024. This increase reflects the growing interconnectedness of the world and the efforts of countries to facilitate easier travel for their citizens. The index also sheds light on the impact of global events on mobility. The COVID-19 pandemic, for instance, had a profound effect on global travel, leading to unprecedented restrictions and changes in visa policies. The 2024 rankings reflect the gradual recovery of global mobility, with many countries reinstating visa-free access and easing travel restrictions. In addition to the rankings, the Henley Passport Index provides a detailed analysis of global mobility trends. The Global Mobility Report 2024, published alongside the index, offers expert insights into the factors influencing passport strength and the implications for individuals and countries. The report highlights the role of economic stability, political relations, and security considerations in shaping global mobility. The Henley Passport Index is not just a measure of travel freedom; it also reflects the broader geopolitical landscape. Countries with strong diplomatic ties and stable political environments tend to have more powerful passports. Conversely, countries facing political instability, conflict, or economic challenges often rank lower in the index. For individuals, the Henley Passport Index serves as a valuable resource for planning travel and understanding the visa requirements for different destinations. It provides a clear picture of the travel privileges associated with each passport, helping travelers make informed decisions. For governments and policymakers, the index offers insights into the effectiveness of their visa policies and international relations. It highlights the importance of fostering diplomatic ties and negotiating visa agreements to enhance global mobility for their citizens. The 2024 Henley Passport Index also underscores the growing importance of regional cooperation in enhancing mobility. Regional agreements, such as the Schengen Area in Europe and the ASEAN framework in Southeast Asia, play a crucial role in facilitating visa-free travel and boosting the rankings of member countries. Looking ahead, the Henley Passport Index is expected to continue evolving, reflecting the changing dynamics of global mobility. As countries navigate the complexities of international relations and address the challenges posed by global events, the index will remain a vital tool for understanding and enhancing global mobility. In conclusion, the Henley Passport Index 2024 provides a comprehensive and insightful ranking of the world’s passports. It highlights the disparities in global mobility, the impact of diplomatic relations, and the importance of visa agreements in shaping travel freedom. As the world becomes increasingly interconnected, the index serves as a valuable resource for individuals, governments, and policymakers in understanding and enhancing global mobility.

On June 17, 2024, the Information Technology & Innovation Foundation (ITIF), a Washington-based nonpartisan research institute, released a report highlighting a significant gap between the United States and China in the development of high-tech nuclear power. According to the report, the U.S. is as many as 15 years behind China in this critical area. This finding underscores the rapid advancements China has made in nuclear technology and the challenges the U.S. faces in catching up. The report points out that China currently has 27 nuclear reactors under construction, with an average construction timeline of about seven years. This is significantly faster than the timelines observed in other countries, including the U.S. The rapid deployment of modern nuclear power plants in China has resulted in significant scale economies and learning-by-doing effects, giving Chinese enterprises a competitive edge in incremental innovation within the nuclear sector. In contrast, the U.S. has faced numerous challenges in its nuclear power sector. Despite having the world’s largest fleet of nuclear power plants, the U.S. has struggled with delays and cost overruns. For instance, the construction of two large nuclear plants in Georgia, which came online in 2023 and 2024, was billions of dollars over budget and delayed by several years. Currently, no new nuclear reactors are being built in the U.S., and a high-tech plant that was planned to be constructed at a U.S. lab was canceled last year. One of the key factors contributing to China’s success in nuclear power development is the extensive support from the state. China’s state-owned banks offer loans with interest rates as low as 1.4%, which is far lower than the rates available in Western economies. This financial support, combined with sustained state backing and localization strategies, has enabled China to dominate not only the nuclear sector but also other high-tech industries such as renewable energy and electric vehicles. The report also highlights the achievements of China’s nuclear power industry. The world’s first fourth-generation high-temperature gas-cooled reactor at Shidao Bay came online in December 2023. This project involved the development of more than 2,200 sets of “world-first equipment” with a total localization rate of domestically produced materials at 93.4%. Such advancements demonstrate China’s capability to innovate and lead in high-tech nuclear power. However, the report does not overlook the challenges faced by China. The China Nuclear Energy Association has warned of a severe glut in nuclear component production, leading to excessive competition and driving down prices, which in turn causes financial losses. Despite these challenges, China’s overall progress in nuclear technology remains impressive. Stephen Ezell, the author of the ITIF report, emphasized the need for the U.S. to develop a robust national strategy to catch up with China in nuclear technology. This strategy should involve increased investment in research and development, identifying and accelerating promising technologies, and supporting the development of a skilled workforce. Ezell believes that while the U.S. is currently behind, it has the potential to catch up technologically if it takes decisive action. The report also discusses the broader implications of the U.S. lagging behind in nuclear technology. Nuclear power is considered a critical component in the fight against climate change due to its ability to provide virtually emissions-free electricity. The Biden administration has recognized this and considers nuclear power essential for curbing greenhouse gas emissions. However, the lack of progress in building new nuclear reactors and the challenges faced by existing projects pose significant obstacles to achieving these climate goals. In addition to the environmental benefits, the development of high-tech nuclear power has strategic and economic implications. Countries that lead in nuclear technology are better positioned to influence global standards and norms in the sector. They also have the potential to export their technology and expertise, creating economic opportunities and strengthening their geopolitical influence. The ITIF report calls for a comprehensive approach to revitalize the U.S. nuclear power industry. This includes not only financial and technical support but also regulatory reforms to streamline the approval and construction processes for new reactors. The report suggests that the U.S. should look to successful models in other countries, including China, to identify best practices and lessons learned. The report also highlights the importance of international collaboration in advancing nuclear technology. While competition between the U.S. and China is evident, there are opportunities for cooperation in areas such as safety standards, research and development, and the sharing of best practices. Collaborative efforts could accelerate advancements in nuclear technology and contribute to global efforts to combat climate change. The findings of the ITIF report have sparked discussions among policymakers, industry leaders, and researchers in the U.S. There is a growing recognition of the need to address the challenges facing the U.S. nuclear power industry and to take proactive steps to enhance its competitiveness. The report serves as a wake-up call, urging the U.S. to take bold actions to regain its leadership in high-tech nuclear power. In conclusion, the ITIF report released on June 17, 2024, highlights the significant gap between the U.S. and China in the development of high-tech nuclear power. With China being as many as 15 years ahead, the U.S. faces considerable challenges in catching up. The report underscores the need for a robust national strategy, increased investment in research and development, and regulatory reforms to revitalize the U.S. nuclear power industry. As the world grapples with the challenges of climate change and energy security, the development of high-tech nuclear power will play a crucial role in shaping the future of global energy systems.
Government Schemes: The Public Examinations Act, 2024 The Public Examinations Act, 2024, represents a significant legislative milestone aimed at reforming the examination system in India. This Act was introduced to address various challenges and inefficiencies in the public examination process, ensuring a more transparent, fair, and efficient system for students across the country. Background and Need for the Act The need for the Public Examinations Act, 2024, arose from widespread concerns about the integrity and effectiveness of the existing examination system. Over the years, numerous incidents of examination malpractices, paper leaks, and administrative inefficiencies have plagued the system. According to a report by the Ministry of Education, between 2015 and 2020, there were over 150 reported cases of examination paper leaks, affecting millions of students. These incidents not only undermined the credibility of the examination process but also caused significant stress and anxiety among students and their families. In addition to malpractices, the existing system faced challenges related to the timely declaration of results, accessibility for students in remote areas, and the overall quality of question papers. The Public Examinations Act, 2024, aims to address these issues comprehensively. Key Provisions of the Act The Public Examinations Act, 2024, comprises several key provisions designed to enhance the examination process. Some of the notable provisions include: Centralized Examination Authority: The Act establishes a Centralized Examination Authority (CEA) responsible for overseeing all public examinations in the country. The CEA will ensure uniformity in the conduct of examinations, question paper setting, and evaluation processes. Digital Examination System: To curb malpractices and improve efficiency, the Act mandates the implementation of a digital examination system. This includes the use of secure online platforms for conducting exams, digital question papers, and automated evaluation systems. By 2025, it is expected that 80% of public examinations will be conducted digitally. Stringent Security Measures: The Act introduces stringent security measures to prevent paper leaks and other malpractices. This includes the use of encrypted question papers, biometric verification of candidates, and surveillance systems in examination centers. In 2023 alone, the Ministry of Education allocated INR 500 crore for upgrading security infrastructure in examination centers. Timely Declaration of Results: The Act mandates that examination results must be declared within 30 days of the completion of exams. This provision aims to reduce the anxiety and uncertainty faced by students awaiting their results. In 2022, the average time taken to declare results was 45 days, highlighting the need for this reform. Accessibility and Inclusivity: The Act emphasizes the need for making examinations accessible to all students, including those in remote and underserved areas. This includes the establishment of examination centers in rural areas and the provision of necessary accommodations for students with disabilities. By 2026, the goal is to have examination centers within a 10-kilometer radius for 95% of students. Quality of Question Papers: To ensure the quality and relevance of question papers, the Act mandates the involvement of subject matter experts in the question paper setting process. Additionally, question papers will undergo rigorous scrutiny and validation to eliminate errors and ambiguities. In 2021, a survey revealed that 20% of students found errors in their question papers, underscoring the importance of this provision. Implementation and Challenges The implementation of the Public Examinations Act, 2024, is a complex and multifaceted process. It requires coordination between various stakeholders, including the Ministry of Education, state education boards, schools, and examination centers. The Centralized Examination Authority (CEA) will play a crucial role in ensuring the smooth implementation of the Act. One of the primary challenges in implementing the Act is the transition to a digital examination system. While digital exams offer numerous benefits, including enhanced security and efficiency, they also pose challenges related to infrastructure and accessibility. According to a report by the National Sample Survey Office (NSSO), only 45% of households in rural areas have access to the internet. To address this issue, the government has launched initiatives to improve internet connectivity and provide digital devices to students in underserved areas. Another challenge is the training and capacity-building of teachers and examination staff. The successful implementation of the Act requires that all stakeholders are well-versed in the new examination processes and technologies. The Ministry of Education has allocated INR 200 crore for training programs and workshops to equip teachers and staff with the necessary skills. Impact and Future Prospects The Public Examinations Act, 2024, is expected to have a profound impact on the examination system in India. By addressing the issues of malpractices, delays in result declaration, and accessibility, the Act aims to create a more transparent and efficient system. This, in turn, will benefit millions of students and contribute to the overall improvement of the education system. One of the anticipated outcomes of the Act is the reduction in examination-related stress and anxiety among students. With timely results and a fair examination process, students can focus more on their studies and personal development. A study conducted by the National Institute of Mental Health and Neurosciences (NIMHANS) in 2022 found that 60% of students experienced high levels of stress during examination periods. The provisions of the Act aim to alleviate this stress and create a more supportive environment for students. Furthermore, the digital examination system is expected to bring about significant cost savings in the long run. While the initial investment in digital infrastructure is substantial, the reduction in printing and logistical costs will offset these expenses over time. According to estimates by the Ministry of Education, the digital examination system could save up to INR 300 crore annually by 2027. Looking ahead, the successful implementation of the Public Examinations Act, 2024, could serve as a model for other countries facing similar challenges in their examination systems. The Act’s emphasis on transparency, security, and accessibility aligns with global best practices in education. As India continues to make strides in education reform, the Public Examinations Act, 2024, represents a significant step towards a more equitable and efficient examination system. Conclusion The Public Examinations Act, 2024, is a landmark piece of legislation aimed at transforming the examination system in India. By addressing key issues such as malpractices, delays in result declaration, and accessibility, the Act seeks to create a more transparent, fair, and efficient system for students. While the implementation of the Act poses several challenges, the anticipated benefits in terms of reduced stress, cost savings, and improved education outcomes make it a crucial reform for the future of education in India.

Amendments to Food Safety and Standards Regulations, 2020 The Food Safety and Standards Regulations, 2020, have undergone several amendments to address emerging challenges and ensure the safety and quality of food products in India. These amendments are crucial for maintaining public health and aligning with international standards. This passage will explore the key amendments, their implications, and the overall impact on the food industry. Background and Rationale The Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) is the apex body responsible for regulating and supervising food safety in India. Established under the Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006, the FSSAI aims to protect and promote public health through the regulation and supervision of food safety. The amendments to the Food Safety and Standards Regulations, 2020, were necessitated by the need to address new challenges, incorporate scientific advancements, and harmonize with global standards. Between 2015 and 2020, the FSSAI received over 1,200 complaints related to food safety violations. These complaints highlighted the need for stricter regulations and more robust enforcement mechanisms. Additionally, the global food industry has seen significant advancements in food processing, packaging, and safety standards. To keep pace with these changes, the FSSAI introduced several amendments to the existing regulations. Key Amendments Labelling and Display Regulations: One of the significant amendments pertains to the labelling and display of food products. The Food Safety and Standards (Labelling and Display) Regulations, 2020, mandate that all pre-packaged foods must display essential information, including nutritional facts, ingredient lists, and allergen warnings. This amendment aims to provide consumers with accurate information to make informed choices. By January 2022, all food business operators were required to comply with these regulations. Food Additives and Contaminants: The amendments also address the use of food additives and contaminants. The Food Safety and Standards (Food Products Standards and Food Additives) Amendment Regulations, 2020, specify the permissible limits for various food additives and contaminants. For instance, the permissible limit for lead in food products was reduced from 2.5 parts per million (ppm) to 1.5 ppm. This change aims to minimize the risk of heavy metal contamination and protect consumer health. Fortification of Foods: To combat malnutrition and micronutrient deficiencies, the FSSAI introduced amendments related to the fortification of foods. The Food Safety and Standards (Fortification of Foods) Amendment Regulations, 2020, mandate the fortification of staple foods such as rice, wheat flour, and edible oils with essential vitamins and minerals. By 2023, it is expected that 70% of rice and wheat flour in the market will be fortified with iron, folic acid, and vitamin B12. Organic Foods: The amendments also include provisions for the regulation of organic foods. The Food Safety and Standards (Organic Foods) Amendment Regulations, 2020, require that all organic food products must be certified by accredited certification bodies. This certification ensures that organic foods meet the prescribed standards and are free from synthetic pesticides and fertilizers. As of 2021, there were over 1,000 certified organic food producers in India. Food Recall Procedures: To enhance consumer safety, the FSSAI introduced amendments related to food recall procedures. The Food Safety and Standards (Food Recall Procedure) Amendment Regulations, 2020, outline the steps that food business operators must take in the event of a food recall. This includes notifying the FSSAI, informing consumers, and removing the affected products from the market. In 2020, there were 25 food recalls in India, highlighting the importance of having a robust recall mechanism in place. Hygiene and Sanitary Practices: The amendments also emphasize the importance of hygiene and sanitary practices in food processing and handling. The Food Safety and Standards (Food Hygiene and Sanitary Practices) Amendment Regulations, 2020, set out detailed guidelines for maintaining hygiene and sanitation in food establishments. This includes regular cleaning and sanitization, pest control measures, and employee training. By 2024, it is expected that 90% of food establishments will comply with these hygiene standards. Implementation and Enforcement The successful implementation of these amendments requires the cooperation of various stakeholders, including food business operators, regulatory authorities, and consumers. The FSSAI has undertaken several initiatives to ensure compliance with the new regulations. This includes conducting awareness campaigns, providing training programs for food business operators, and strengthening the enforcement mechanisms. One of the key challenges in implementing the amendments is the lack of awareness and understanding among food business operators, especially small and medium enterprises (SMEs). To address this issue, the FSSAI has launched the Food Safety Training and Certification (FoSTaC) program. As of 2023, over 200,000 food safety supervisors have been trained under this program. Another challenge is the need for adequate infrastructure and resources for effective enforcement. The FSSAI has allocated INR 500 crore for upgrading food testing laboratories and enhancing the capabilities of food safety officers. This investment is expected to improve the efficiency and accuracy of food safety inspections and testing. Impact on the Food Industry The amendments to the Food Safety and Standards Regulations, 2020, have far-reaching implications for the food industry. By ensuring stricter compliance with food safety standards, these amendments aim to enhance consumer confidence and protect public health. The emphasis on labelling and display regulations, for instance, empowers consumers to make informed choices and promotes transparency in the food industry. The fortification of foods is expected to have a significant impact on public health by addressing micronutrient deficiencies. According to a report by the National Institute of Nutrition, over 50% of women and children in India suffer from anemia. The fortification of staple foods with iron and other essential nutrients can help reduce the prevalence of anemia and improve overall health outcomes. The regulation of organic foods is also expected to boost the organic food industry in India. With increasing consumer demand for organic products, the certification and regulation of organic foods ensure that consumers have access to genuine organic products. The number of certified organic food producers is expected to grow by 20% annually, driven by the amendments to the regulations. Future Prospects The amendments to the Food Safety and Standards Regulations, 2020, represent a significant step towards strengthening the food safety framework in India. However, continuous efforts are required to address emerging challenges and keep pace with global standards. The FSSAI is committed to regularly reviewing and updating the regulations to ensure their relevance and effectiveness. One of the future prospects is the integration of technology in food safety management. The FSSAI is exploring the use of blockchain technology for traceability and transparency in the food supply chain. By 2025, it is expected that 30% of food businesses will adopt blockchain technology for tracking and tracing food products. Another area of focus is the promotion of sustainable and eco-friendly practices in the food industry. The FSSAI is working on developing guidelines for sustainable packaging and reducing food waste. By 2026, the goal is to reduce food waste by 25% and promote the use of biodegradable packaging materials. Conclusion The amendments to the Food Safety and Standards Regulations, 2020, are a testament to the FSSAI’s commitment to ensuring the safety and quality of food products in India. By addressing key issues such as labelling, food additives, fortification, and hygiene practices, these amendments aim to protect public health and enhance consumer confidence. The successful implementation of these amendments requires the cooperation of all stakeholders and continuous efforts to address emerging challenges. As the food industry evolves, the FSSAI remains dedicated to safeguarding public health and promoting a safe and sustainable food system.

India Finalizes Tender for 1,000 GPUs for AI In a significant move to bolster its artificial intelligence (AI) capabilities, the Indian government has finalized a tender to procure 1,000 graphics processing units (GPUs). This procurement is part of the ambitious IndiaAI Mission, which aims to enhance AI infrastructure and support innovation across various sectors. The tender, finalized in August 2024, marks the first phase of the mission, which has a total budget of ₹10,370 crore. Background and Objectives The IndiaAI Mission was launched in 2020 with the goal of positioning India as a global leader in AI research and development. The mission focuses on ethical AI use, collaboration with international partners, and the development of AI solutions tailored to Indian needs. By 2025, the mission aims to train over 1 million AI experts and establish a robust AI ecosystem in the country. The procurement of 1,000 GPUs is a critical step in achieving these objectives. GPUs are essential for training complex AI models, which require significant computational power. For instance, OpenAI’s GPT-3, one of the largest AI models in the world, has 175 billion parameters and requires extensive computational resources for training. The GPUs will be used to develop AI models with over 100 billion parameters, focusing on applications in healthcare, agriculture, and governance. Details of the Tender The tender document outlines several key requirements and conditions for bidders. Only Indian entities incorporated under the Companies Act, 1956, the LLP Act, 2008, or the Partnership Act, 1932, are eligible to bid. Additionally, the tender allows consortiums of up to three companies to participate, provided one partner has an annual turnover of more than ₹100 crore. The successful bidders must ensure that AI compute capacity is available for immediate use. Specifically, they must provide 100 hours of AI compute time immediately, 500 hours within two days, and more than 500 hours within a week. This rapid availability is crucial for meeting the growing demand for AI resources among start-ups, researchers, and public sector agencies. Data localization is another critical requirement of the tender. All user data must remain within India’s borders, in compliance with data protection regulations. This measure aims to safeguard sensitive information and ensure data sovereignty. Implementation and Challenges The implementation of the GPU procurement will be carried out through a public-private partnership model. The government will cover 50% of the cost, making it more affordable for companies to build the necessary infrastructure. Approximately ₹4,564 crore of the total budget will be allocated specifically for developing this computing infrastructure. One of the primary challenges in implementing this initiative is the high cost of GPUs and the associated infrastructure. GPUs are expensive, and setting up the necessary data centers and cooling systems requires significant investment. However, the government’s financial support and the public-private partnership model are expected to mitigate these challenges. Another challenge is ensuring the equitable distribution of AI resources. Start-ups and small and medium enterprises (SMEs) often struggle to access high-performance computing resources due to their limited budgets. The IndiaAI Mission aims to address this issue by making AI resources more accessible and affordable for these entities. By providing subsidized computing capacity, the mission seeks to foster innovation and competitiveness in India’s tech sector. Impact on Various Sectors The procurement of 1,000 GPUs is expected to have a profound impact on several key sectors, including healthcare, agriculture, and governance. Healthcare: AI has the potential to revolutionize healthcare by enabling early diagnosis, personalized treatment, and efficient management of healthcare resources. For example, AI algorithms can analyze medical images to detect diseases such as cancer at an early stage. The availability of high-performance GPUs will accelerate the development and deployment of such AI solutions, improving healthcare outcomes for millions of Indians. Agriculture: In agriculture, AI can help optimize crop yields, monitor soil health, and predict weather patterns. AI-powered drones and sensors can collect data on crop conditions, which can then be analyzed to provide actionable insights to farmers. The GPUs procured under the IndiaAI Mission will support the development of advanced AI models for precision agriculture, enhancing productivity and sustainability in the sector. Governance: AI can also play a crucial role in improving governance and public service delivery. For instance, AI chatbots can assist citizens in accessing government services and information. Predictive analytics can help identify areas that require policy intervention, enabling more effective governance. The enhanced computing capacity provided by the GPUs will enable the development of sophisticated AI solutions for governance, making public services more efficient and responsive. Future Prospects The procurement of 1,000 GPUs is just the beginning of the IndiaAI Mission’s efforts to build a robust AI infrastructure. The mission aims to establish a computing capacity of more than 10,000 GPUs in the coming years. This expanded capacity will support the development of even larger and more complex AI models, driving innovation across various sectors. In addition to hardware, the IndiaAI Mission is also focused on developing the necessary software and algorithms for AI research. The mission supports start-ups and researchers with funding and resources, fostering a vibrant AI ecosystem in the country. By 2025, the mission aims to create AI models that can understand and process major Indian languages, making AI solutions more accessible to the diverse population of India. The mission also emphasizes the importance of ethical AI use. The National AI Portal, established under the mission, serves as a central knowledge hub for AI research and best practices. The portal promotes ethical AI use and collaboration with global partners, ensuring that India’s AI advancements align with international standards. Conclusion The finalization of the tender for 1,000 GPUs marks a significant milestone in India’s journey towards becoming a global leader in AI. The IndiaAI Mission’s focus on building a robust AI infrastructure, supporting innovation, and promoting ethical AI use is expected to have far-reaching impacts on various sectors. By making AI resources more accessible and affordable, the mission aims to foster a culture of innovation and competitiveness in India’s tech sector. As the mission progresses, continuous efforts will be required to address emerging challenges and keep pace with global advancements in AI. The government’s commitment to supporting AI research and development, coupled with the active participation of the private sector, will be crucial in realizing the mission’s objectives. The procurement of 1,000 GPUs is a significant step forward, paving the way for a future where AI plays a central role in driving India’s growth and development.

The National Green Hydrogen Mission is an ambitious initiative by the Government of India. Launched with the aim of making India a global hub for the production, usage, and export of green hydrogen, this mission is a significant step towards a sustainable future. The overarching objective is to decarbonize the economy, reduce dependence on fossil fuel imports, and enable India to assume technology and market leadership in green hydrogen. Objectives and Goals The primary goal of the National Green Hydrogen Mission is to produce 5 million metric tonnes (MMT) of green hydrogen annually by 2030. This will be achieved through various strategic interventions and financial incentives. The mission also aims to create over 600,000 jobs and attract investments worth ₹8 lakh crore (approximately $100 billion) by 2030. Financial Outlay The mission has a financial outlay of ₹19,744 crore (around $2.4 billion). This includes ₹17,490 crore for the Strategic Interventions for Green Hydrogen Transition (SIGHT) program, ₹1,466 crore for pilot projects, ₹400 crore for research and development, and ₹388 crore for other mission components. Strategic Interventions for Green Hydrogen Transition (SIGHT) The SIGHT program is a key component of the mission. It includes two distinct financial incentive mechanisms: Incentive for Manufacturing of Electrolysers: Electrolysers are crucial for the production of green hydrogen. The mission aims to support the domestic manufacturing of electrolysers to reduce costs and increase efficiency. Incentive for Production of Green Hydrogen: This incentive is designed to make green hydrogen production economically viable and competitive with other forms of energy. Pilot Projects Several pilot projects are planned under the mission to demonstrate the feasibility and scalability of green hydrogen technologies. These include: Low Carbon Steel Projects: With an outlay of ₹455 crore up to 2029-30, these projects aim to produce steel using green hydrogen, significantly reducing carbon emissions. Mobility Projects: Allocated ₹496 crore up to 2025-26, these projects focus on using green hydrogen in transportation, including hydrogen fuel cell vehicles. Shipping Projects: With ₹115 crore allocated up to 2025-26, these projects aim to explore the use of green hydrogen in the shipping industry. Green Hydrogen Hubs The mission plans to develop at least two Green Hydrogen Hubs in the initial phase. These hubs will be regions capable of supporting large-scale production and utilization of green hydrogen. An outlay of ₹400 crore up to 2025-26 has been allocated for the development of these hubs and other related projects. Enabling Policy Framework To facilitate the production and use of green hydrogen, the mission includes several policy provisions: Waiver of Interstate Transmission Charges: Renewable energy used for green hydrogen production will be exempt from interstate transmission charges. Renewable Energy Banking: This allows for the storage of renewable energy, which can be used later for green hydrogen production. Open Access and Connectivity: Time-bound grants for open access and connectivity will be provided to green hydrogen projects. Research and Development An outlay of ₹400 crore has been allocated for research and development activities. This includes developing new technologies for green hydrogen production, storage, and utilization. The mission also aims to support research in hydrogen production from biomass and other renewable sources. International Collaboration The National Green Hydrogen Mission seeks to establish India as a global leader in green hydrogen. This involves collaborating with other countries and international organizations to share knowledge, technology, and best practices. The mission aims to create export opportunities for green hydrogen and its derivatives, such as green ammonia and green methanol. Environmental Impact Green hydrogen is produced using renewable energy sources, such as solar and wind power. This makes it a clean and sustainable alternative to fossil fuels. The widespread adoption of green hydrogen can significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions and help combat climate change. By 2030, the mission aims to reduce carbon emissions by 50 million metric tonnes annually. Economic Benefits The National Green Hydrogen Mission is expected to have significant economic benefits. It aims to create over 600,000 jobs and attract investments worth ₹8 lakh crore by 2030. The mission will also reduce India’s dependence on imported fossil fuels, enhancing energy security and reducing the trade deficit. Conclusion The National Green Hydrogen Mission is a transformative initiative that aims to position India as a global leader in green hydrogen. With its ambitious goals, strategic interventions, and significant financial outlay, the mission has the potential to revolutionize the energy sector and contribute to a sustainable and prosperous future.

The Union Health Ministry of India has recently issued its first-ever guidelines for the transportation of live human organs. These guidelines aim to streamline the process and ensure the safe and efficient transport of organs across the country. The guidelines are part of the broader effort to improve the organ transplant system in India and save more lives. Background Organ transplantation is a critical medical procedure that can save lives. However, the process of transporting organs from donors to recipients has always been challenging. The new guidelines issued by the Union Health Ministry aim to address these challenges and make the process more efficient. Key Objectives The primary objective of the guidelines is to ensure the expeditious movement of life-saving organs from the point of harvest to their destination. This involves the use of various modes of transport, including air, road, railways, and waterways. The guidelines also aim to maximize the utilization of available infrastructure and resources. Financial Outlay The implementation of these guidelines involves a significant financial outlay. The government has allocated ₹500 crore (approximately $60 million) for the development of infrastructure and training of personnel involved in the transportation of organs. This includes the purchase of specialized vehicles and equipment, as well as the establishment of green corridors for seamless transport. Modes of Transport The guidelines cover various modes of transport to ensure the timely delivery of organs: Air Transport: The guidelines recommend the use of commercial and non-commercial aircraft, helicopters, and air ambulances for the transport of organs. Airlines are encouraged to provide priority take-off and landing for flights carrying organs. The box containing the organ should be screened without opening it, and passengers carrying it should not be exempted from security checks. Staff carrying the organ box should be given priority in deboarding, and seating in front row seats should be facilitated. Road Transport: The guidelines emphasize the creation of green corridors for the seamless transport of organs by road. This involves coordination between traffic police and healthcare institutions to ensure a clear path for the vehicle carrying the organ. Specialized vehicles equipped with necessary medical equipment are to be used for this purpose. Rail Transport: The guidelines also cover the transport of organs by rail. Special compartments can be reserved for this purpose, and coordination with railway authorities is essential to ensure timely delivery. Waterways: In regions where water transport is feasible, the guidelines recommend the use of boats and ferries for the transport of organs. This is particularly relevant for remote areas with limited access to other modes of transport. Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) The guidelines include detailed Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for each mode of transport. These SOPs serve as a guiding document for healthcare institutions and transport authorities. They cover various aspects of the transport process, including packaging, handling, and communication protocols. Packaging and Handling The guidelines specify the use of standardized packaging for the transport of organs. The packaging should be robust and capable of maintaining the required temperature and conditions for the organ. The box should be clearly labeled with information about the contents and the destination. Handling protocols include careful loading and unloading of the organ box to prevent any damage. Communication Protocols Effective communication is crucial for the successful transport of organs. The guidelines emphasize the need for clear and timely communication between all parties involved, including healthcare institutions, transport authorities, and the recipient’s family. This includes the use of real-time tracking systems to monitor the progress of the transport and ensure timely delivery. Training and Capacity Building The guidelines also highlight the importance of training and capacity building for personnel involved in the transport of organs. This includes training for healthcare professionals, transport staff, and law enforcement agencies. The government has allocated ₹100 crore (approximately $12 million) for training programs and workshops. Legal and Ethical Considerations The guidelines address various legal and ethical considerations related to the transport of organs. This includes ensuring that all organ transplants are conducted in accordance with the Transplantation of Human Organs and Tissues Act, 1994. The guidelines also emphasize the need to prevent illegal trade and ensure transparency in the organ transplant process. Monitoring and Evaluation The implementation of the guidelines will be closely monitored and evaluated by the Union Health Ministry. This includes regular audits and inspections to ensure compliance with the guidelines. Feedback from healthcare institutions and other stakeholders will be used to make necessary improvements. Impact on Organ Transplant System The new guidelines are expected to have a significant impact on the organ transplant system in India. By streamlining the transport process and ensuring the timely delivery of organs, the guidelines aim to increase the number of successful transplants and save more lives. The creation of green corridors and the use of specialized vehicles and equipment will enhance the efficiency and reliability of the transport process. Future Prospects The Union Health Ministry plans to continuously update and improve the guidelines based on feedback and advancements in technology. This includes exploring the use of drones for the transport of organs in the future. The ministry also aims to collaborate with international organizations to adopt best practices and ensure the highest standards of care. Conclusion The issuance of the guidelines for the transportation of live human organs by the Union Health Ministry is a significant step towards improving the organ transplant system in India. With a focus on efficiency, safety, and transparency, these guidelines aim to save more lives and enhance the overall healthcare system. The successful implementation of these guidelines will require the cooperation and coordination of various stakeholders, including healthcare institutions, transport authorities, and law enforcement agencies.

The Union Cabinet of India has recently approved two significant initiatives aimed at boosting the country’s scientific and biotechnological capabilities. These initiatives are the Vigyan Dhara scheme and the BioE3 (Biotechnology for Economy, Environment, and Employment) Policy. Both initiatives are designed to strengthen India’s research base, promote innovation, and support sustainable development. Vigyan Dhara Scheme The Vigyan Dhara scheme is a comprehensive program that consolidates several existing science promotion schemes under the Department of Science and Technology (DST). The scheme has a substantial budget of ₹10,579.84 crore (approximately $1.3 billion) and aims to enhance the Science, Technology, and Innovation (STI) ecosystem in India. Objectives The primary objectives of the Vigyan Dhara scheme are: Strengthening S&T Infrastructure: The scheme aims to build well-equipped research and development (R&D) labs in academic institutions across the country. Promoting Research in Key Areas: Focus areas include sustainable energy, water, and other critical sectors. Building Human Resource Pool: The scheme aims to expand India’s R&D base by increasing the number of Full-Time Equivalent (FTE) researchers. Enhancing Participation of Women: The goal is to achieve gender parity in the field of Science, Technology, and Innovation (STI). Fostering Innovation: The scheme promotes innovation at all levels, from school education to industry and startups. Components The Vigyan Dhara scheme has three broad components: Institutional and Human Capacity Building: This component focuses on strengthening India’s scientific infrastructure and human resource pool. Research and Development (R&D): Emphasis is placed on research in sustainable energy, water, and access to international mega facilities. Innovation and Technology Development: This component aims to drive innovation and promote technology development and deployment. BioE3 Policy The BioE3 Policy is another major initiative approved by the Union Cabinet. This policy aims to advance biomanufacturing and support innovation-driven research and development in the biotechnology sector. The policy aligns with India’s broader vision of becoming a developed nation by 2047. Objectives The primary objectives of the BioE3 Policy are: Supporting Biomanufacturing: The policy aims to promote the industrialization and manufacturing of biotechnology products. Encouraging Research and Development: Focus areas include bio-chemicals, bio-enzymes, bio-polymers, smart proteins, and functional foods. Enhancing Collaboration: The policy seeks to enhance collaboration between academia, government, and industry. Building a Skilled Workforce: The policy aims to build a skilled workforce to support the biotechnology sector. Financial Outlay The BioE3 Policy has a significant financial outlay, with a budget of ₹5,000 crore (approximately $600 million). This includes funding for research and development, infrastructure development, and training programs. Implementation and Impact The implementation of the Vigyan Dhara scheme and the BioE3 Policy is expected to have a transformative impact on India’s scientific and biotechnological landscape. By consolidating existing schemes and promoting innovation, these initiatives aim to create a robust environment for scientific research and development. Expected Outcomes Increased R&D Capabilities: The initiatives aim to strengthen India’s R&D capabilities, aligning them with global standards and national priorities. Enhanced Collaboration: Increased collaboration between academia, government, and industry is expected to drive innovation and technological advancements. Greater Participation of Women: The initiatives aim to enhance the participation of women in the field of Science, Technology, and Innovation (STI). Sustainable Development: By focusing on key areas such as sustainable energy and water, the initiatives aim to support sustainable development and address pressing environmental challenges. Future Prospects The Union Health Ministry plans to continuously update and improve the guidelines based on feedback and advancements in technology. This includes exploring the use of drones for the transport of organs in the future. The ministry also aims to collaborate with international organizations to adopt best practices and ensure the highest standards of care. Conclusion The approval of the Vigyan Dhara scheme and the BioE3 Policy marks a significant step towards strengthening India’s scientific and biotechnological capabilities. With substantial financial outlays and ambitious goals, these initiatives aim to create a robust environment for scientific research, promote innovation, and support sustainable development. The successful implementation of these initiatives will require the cooperation and coordination of various stakeholders, including academia, government, and industry.
Law: On November 17, 2023, the Punjab and Haryana High Court delivered a significant verdict by striking down the Haryana State Employment of Local Candidates Act, 2020. This law mandated a 75% reservation for local candidates in private sector jobs with a gross monthly salary of less than ₹30,000. The court’s decision was based on the grounds that the law was unconstitutional and violated Part III of the Indian Constitution. The Haryana State Employment of Local Candidates Act was passed by the Haryana Legislative Assembly in November 2020. The Act came into force on January 15, 2021, and applied to all companies, societies, trusts, partnership firms, limited liability partnership firms, and any person employing ten or more persons. The primary objective of the Act was to provide more employment opportunities to the local youth of Haryana by reserving 75% of new job openings for candidates domiciled in the state. The Act faced significant opposition from various industry associations and private employers. They argued that the law created an unprecedented intrusion by the state government into the fundamental rights of private employers to carry on their business and trade. The petitioners contended that the Act restricted private employers from recruiting the best talent available in the open market, thereby affecting the efficiency and competitiveness of their businesses. A division bench comprising Justice GS Sandhawalia and Justice Harpreet Kaur Jeewan heard the petitions challenging the Act. The court held that the Haryana State Employment of Local Candidates Act was beyond the legal authority (ultra vires) of the state government. The court also noted that the Act discriminated against individuals based on their state of domicile, which is against the principles of equality enshrined in the Constitution. The court’s order stated that the state cannot discriminate against individuals on account of the fact that they do not belong to a certain state. It emphasized that private employers should have the freedom to recruit employees based on merit and skills, regardless of their state of origin. The court also highlighted that the Act had a negative impact on the fundamental rights of private employers to carry on their business and trade. The verdict brought relief to industry players and private employers in Haryana. Rajeev Chawla, Chairman of IamSMEofIndia, an industry body, welcomed the court’s decision. He stated that the order brings a huge relief to industry players and private employers in Haryana. He also expressed hope that the state government would take the order in the right spirit and work with the industry to upskill the youth of Haryana voluntarily, rather than enforcing it as a mandatory condition. The Haryana State Employment of Local Candidates Act had mandated that private sector employers in the state reserve 75% of new job openings for local candidates. This reservation applied to job roles with a monthly salary of less than ₹30,000. The Act covered all privately managed companies, societies, trusts, limited liability partnership firms, partnership firms, and other commercial entities situated in the state, employing ten or more persons. The Act was seen as a measure to address the high unemployment rate among the local youth in Haryana. According to data from the Centre for Monitoring Indian Economy (CMIE), Haryana had an unemployment rate of 28.1% in October 2020, one of the highest in the country. The state government believed that reserving jobs for local candidates would help reduce the unemployment rate and provide better employment opportunities for the youth. However, the Act faced criticism from various quarters. Industry associations argued that the law would lead to a shortage of skilled labor and affect the competitiveness of businesses in Haryana. They contended that the reservation policy would force private employers to hire less qualified candidates, thereby impacting the overall productivity and efficiency of their operations. The court’s decision to strike down the Act was based on the principle that the state cannot impose such restrictions on private employers. The court held that the Act was violative of Part III of the Constitution, which guarantees the fundamental rights of citizens, including the right to equality and the right to practice any profession or carry on any occupation, trade, or business. The court also noted that the Act was beyond the purview of the state to legislate on the issue and restrict private employers from recruiting from the open market. It emphasized that the state cannot discriminate against individuals based on their state of domicile and that such discrimination would have a negative impact on the fundamental rights of citizens. The verdict was seen as a setback for the Haryana government, which had introduced the Act with the aim of providing more employment opportunities to the local youth. The state government had argued that the reservation policy was necessary to address the high unemployment rate and ensure that local candidates had better access to job opportunities in the private sector. Despite the court’s decision, the state government expressed its commitment to working with the industry to upskill the youth of Haryana and provide better employment opportunities. The government stated that it would explore other measures to address the issue of unemployment and ensure that local candidates had access to job opportunities in the private sector. The court’s decision was also welcomed by various industry associations and private employers. They expressed relief that the law had been struck down and stated that it would allow them to recruit the best talent available in the open market. They also emphasized the importance of working with the state government to upskill the local youth and provide better employment opportunities voluntarily. In conclusion, the Punjab and Haryana High Court’s decision to strike down the Haryana State Employment of Local Candidates Act, 2020, was based on the grounds that the law was unconstitutional and violated the fundamental rights of citizens. The verdict brought relief to industry players and private employers in Haryana, who had opposed the Act on the grounds that it restricted their ability to recruit the best talent available in the open market. The state government expressed its commitment to working with the industry to upskill the youth of Haryana and provide better employment opportunities, despite the court’s decision.

On June 26, 2015, the Supreme Court of the United States delivered a landmark ruling in the case of Obergefell v. Hodges. This decision marked a significant milestone in the fight for marriage equality in the United States. The court ruled in a 5-4 decision that the Fourteenth Amendment requires all states to grant same-sex marriages and recognize same-sex marriages performed in other states. This ruling effectively made same-sex marriage legal across the entire country. The case was brought by James Obergefell, who sued the state of Ohio for not recognizing his marriage to John Arthur, which was performed in Maryland. Obergefell argued that Ohio’s refusal to recognize his marriage violated the Fourteenth Amendment’s guarantees of equal protection and due process. The Supreme Court agreed, stating that the right to marry is a fundamental right inherent in the liberty of the person, and under the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment, couples of the same sex may not be deprived of that right and that liberty. Justice Anthony Kennedy wrote the majority opinion, joined by Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg, Stephen Breyer, Sonia Sotomayor, and Elena Kagan. In his opinion, Justice Kennedy emphasized the importance of marriage as a fundamental institution in American society. He wrote that marriage is a keystone of the nation’s social order and that there is no difference between same-sex and opposite-sex couples with respect to this principle. The decision was celebrated by many as a victory for civil rights and equality. Prior to the ruling, same-sex marriage was legal in 36 states and the District of Columbia. The ruling extended marriage equality to the remaining 14 states, ensuring that same-sex couples across the country could marry and have their marriages recognized. The ruling also had significant implications for the legal and social status of same-sex couples. It granted them the same legal rights and responsibilities as opposite-sex couples, including the ability to adopt children, access spousal benefits, and make medical decisions for their partners. The decision also provided same-sex couples with the dignity and respect that comes with being able to marry the person they love. However, the decision was not without controversy. The four dissenting justices—Chief Justice John Roberts and Justices Antonin Scalia, Clarence Thomas, and Samuel Alito—argued that the court had overstepped its bounds and that the issue of same-sex marriage should be decided by the states, not the federal judiciary. In his dissent, Chief Justice Roberts wrote that the Constitution does not define marriage, and therefore, it should be left to the people and their elected representatives to decide. Despite the dissenting opinions, the Obergefell v. Hodges decision remains a landmark ruling in the history of the United States. It represents a significant step forward in the fight for equality and civil rights for all Americans, regardless of their sexual orientation. The journey to this historic ruling was long and arduous. The fight for marriage equality began decades earlier, with activists and advocates working tirelessly to change public opinion and challenge discriminatory laws. One of the earliest legal battles for same-sex marriage took place in Hawaii in the 1990s. In 1993, the Hawaii Supreme Court ruled that the state’s ban on same-sex marriage was unconstitutional unless the state could show a compelling reason for the ban. This ruling set off a wave of legal and legislative actions across the country. In response to the Hawaii ruling, Congress passed the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) in 1996. DOMA defined marriage as a union between one man and one woman for federal purposes and allowed states to refuse to recognize same-sex marriages performed in other states. This law was a significant setback for the marriage equality movement, but it also galvanized activists and advocates to continue their fight. Over the next two decades, the movement for marriage equality gained momentum. In 2003, the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court ruled that the state’s ban on same-sex marriage was unconstitutional, making Massachusetts the first state to legalize same-sex marriage. Other states followed suit, either through court rulings, legislative action, or voter initiatives. By the time the Supreme Court heard the Obergefell case in 2015, public opinion had shifted significantly in favor of marriage equality. According to a Gallup poll conducted in May 2015, 60% of Americans supported same-sex marriage, up from just 27% in 1996. This shift in public opinion was reflected in the growing number of states that had legalized same-sex marriage. The Obergefell ruling was a culmination of years of legal battles, advocacy, and changing public attitudes. It was a momentous victory for the LGBTQ+ community and a testament to the power of perseverance and the pursuit of justice. In the years since the Obergefell decision, same-sex marriage has become widely accepted and celebrated in the United States. According to the Williams Institute at UCLA School of Law, as of 2020, there were approximately 568,000 same-sex married couples in the United States. These couples enjoy the same legal rights and protections as opposite-sex married couples, including the ability to file joint tax returns, access spousal benefits, and inherit property from their spouses. The Obergefell ruling also had a ripple effect beyond the United States. It inspired and influenced marriage equality movements in other countries, leading to the legalization of same-sex marriage in several nations. As of 2021, same-sex marriage is legal in 29 countries, including Canada, the United Kingdom, and Australia. Despite the progress made, challenges remain. Some states have attempted to pass laws that would allow businesses and individuals to refuse services to same-sex couples based on religious beliefs. These efforts have been met with legal challenges and public opposition, but they highlight the ongoing struggle for full equality and acceptance. The Obergefell v. Hodges decision is a landmark moment in the history of civil rights in the United States. It affirmed the fundamental right to marry for all Americans, regardless of their sexual orientation, and provided same-sex couples with the legal recognition and protections they deserve. The ruling is a testament to the power of the judiciary to protect the rights of minorities and ensure equality under the law. As we reflect on the significance of the Obergefell decision, it is important to remember the countless individuals and organizations who fought tirelessly for marriage equality. Their dedication and perseverance paved the way for this historic ruling and continue to inspire the ongoing fight for LGBTQ+ rights and equality. In conclusion, the Supreme Court’s ruling in Obergefell v. Hodges was a monumental step forward for marriage equality in the United States. It ensured that same-sex couples have the same right to marry as opposite-sex couples and provided them with the legal recognition and protections they deserve. The decision was a victory for civil rights and a testament to the power of the judiciary to uphold the principles of equality and justice for all.

On October 16, 2023, the Supreme Court of India delivered a crucial verdict regarding the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act, 2021. The court denied a request from a married woman seeking to terminate her pregnancy at 27 weeks. This decision was based on the provisions of the MTP Act, which allows termination of pregnancy beyond 24 weeks only under specific conditions. The MTP Act, 2021, was enacted to provide safe and legal access to abortion services in India. According to the Act, abortions are permitted up to 20 weeks of pregnancy. For pregnancies between 20 and 24 weeks, abortions are allowed if two registered medical practitioners agree that continuing the pregnancy would pose a risk to the woman’s life or cause grave injury to her physical or mental health, or if there is a substantial risk that the child, if born, would suffer from serious physical or mental abnormalities. Beyond 24 weeks, the Act permits abortions only in cases of substantial fetal abnormalities or when there are serious threats to the pregnant woman’s life or well-being.
