This is slightly higher than the levels found in a previous study conducted in 1986, which recorded an average of 89 nGy/hr. However, the most striking finding was in the Kollam district of Kerala, where the levels were measured at 9,562 nGy/hr. This is about three times more than the previously assumed levels and translates to approximately 70 milligray per year. Gamma radiation is a type of ionizing radiation that can penetrate through most materials, including human tissue. While low levels of gamma radiation are generally harmless, prolonged exposure to higher levels can pose health risks. Despite the elevated levels in Kollam, the study found no significant increase in cancer rates or mortality, suggesting that the local population may have adapted to these higher levels of radiation. The high background radiation levels in Kerala are primarily due to the presence of monazite sands, which are rich in thorium. Thorium is a naturally occurring radioactive element that is used in nuclear fuel production. The monazite sands are particularly abundant in the coastal areas of Kerala, contributing to the elevated radiation levels. Additionally, the region’s geology, which includes granite and basaltic volcanic rocks, also contains higher concentrations of uranium, another source of natural radiation. To put these findings into perspective, it is essential to understand the concept of background radiation. Background radiation refers to the ionizing radiation present in the environment that is not due to any deliberate introduction of radiation sources. It comes from both natural sources, such as cosmic rays and radioactive elements in the earth’s crust, and artificial sources, including medical procedures and nuclear power plants. The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) has established maximum radiation exposure levels to ensure public safety. For the general public, the maximum allowable exposure is 1 millisievert per year, while for individuals working in radiation-related occupations, the limit is 30 millisieverts per year. The levels found in Kollam, at approximately 70 milligray per year, are higher than the occupational exposure limit, but it is important to note that these levels are still considered safe for the general population. The discovery of higher background radiation levels in Kerala has prompted further research into the potential health impacts. Studies have shown that the human body can adapt to higher levels of radiation over time, a phenomenon known as radiation hormesis. This adaptation may explain why the local population in Kollam has not shown increased rates of radiation-related illnesses. However, long-term studies are needed to fully understand the implications of prolonged exposure to elevated radiation levels. In addition to health impacts, the economic implications of high background radiation levels are also significant. The presence of monazite sands in Kerala has long been recognized as a valuable resource for thorium extraction, which is used in nuclear fuel production. India has one of the largest reserves of thorium in the world, and the elevated radiation levels in Kerala highlight the potential for further exploration and utilization of this resource. Efforts to monitor and manage background radiation levels in Kerala are ongoing. The BARC study has provided valuable data that can be used to improve radiation safety protocols and public health measures. For instance, regular monitoring of radiation levels in high-risk areas can help identify any changes over time and ensure that appropriate safety measures are in place. Public awareness campaigns can also educate residents about the sources and potential risks of background radiation, promoting safer practices and reducing unnecessary exposure. Technological advancements have also played a crucial role in improving radiation monitoring and safety. The use of low-cost sensors and satellite data has enhanced the ability to track radiation levels in real-time, providing more accurate and timely information. Additionally, innovations in nuclear technology, such as the development of thorium-based reactors, offer promising solutions for utilizing the region’s natural resources while minimizing environmental and health risks. International cooperation is another important aspect of addressing the challenges posed by high background radiation levels. Countries facing similar issues can share best practices and collaborate on research and development efforts. For example, China has made significant progress in reducing radiation exposure through strict regulations and investments in clean energy technologies. India can learn from these experiences and adapt them to its own context, ensuring that the benefits of natural resources are maximized while minimizing potential risks. In conclusion, the discovery that background radiation levels in parts of Kerala are nearly three times higher than previously assumed has significant implications for environmental monitoring, public health, and economic development. While the elevated levels do not currently pose a significant health risk, ongoing research and monitoring are essential to ensure the safety and well-being of the local population. By leveraging technological advancements, promoting public awareness, and fostering international cooperation, India can effectively manage the challenges and opportunities presented by its unique natural resources.

California has recently been hit by a second atmospheric river in a span of just a few days, causing widespread disruption and damage across the state. An atmospheric river is a narrow corridor of concentrated moisture in the atmosphere, capable of transporting large amounts of water vapor from the tropics to mid-latitude regions. When this moisture-laden air makes landfall, it can result in heavy rainfall, strong winds, and severe flooding. The first atmospheric river struck California on February 1, 2024, bringing with it torrential rains and high winds. This initial storm caused significant flooding in Northern California, particularly in the San Francisco Bay Area. Roads were submerged, power lines were downed, and thousands of residents were left without electricity. The storm also triggered mudslides in several areas, leading to road closures and evacuations. Just as the state was beginning to recover, a second atmospheric river arrived on February 4, 2024. This storm was even more intense, with meteorologists warning of possible hurricane-force winds and further flooding. The National Weather Service issued flash flood warnings for several counties, including Los Angeles, Ventura, and Santa Barbara. The second storm brought record levels of rainfall to Southern California, with some areas receiving over 10 inches of rain in just 24 hours. The impact of these back-to-back atmospheric rivers has been devastating. In Northern California, the city of San Jose experienced severe flooding, with the Guadalupe River overflowing its banks and inundating nearby neighborhoods. Rescue workers were deployed to evacuate residents from flooded homes and to assist those stranded in their vehicles. In Alameda, high winds and heavy rain caused waves to crash over breakwaters, damaging boats and waterfront properties. In Southern California, the situation was equally dire. The city of Los Angeles saw historic levels of rainfall, leading to mudslides and rockfalls in the surrounding hills. The Beverly Crest area was particularly hard hit, with mud and debris flowing down hillsides and damaging homes. Power outages affected over a million people across the state, with utility companies working around the clock to restore electricity. The economic impact of these storms has been significant. Preliminary estimates suggest that the damage caused by the two atmospheric rivers could exceed $1 billion. This includes the cost of repairing infrastructure, such as roads and bridges, as well as the economic losses from business closures and disrupted transportation. The agricultural sector has also been affected, with flooding damaging crops and delaying planting schedules. The environmental impact of the storms has also been considerable. The heavy rainfall has led to increased runoff, which can carry pollutants into rivers and streams. This can harm aquatic ecosystems and degrade water quality. Additionally, the strong winds have uprooted trees and damaged vegetation, which can lead to soil erosion and habitat loss. The response to the storms has involved a coordinated effort from multiple agencies. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) has been working with state and local authorities to provide assistance to affected communities. This includes deploying search and rescue teams, setting up emergency shelters, and distributing supplies such as food and water. The California National Guard has also been activated to assist with rescue operations and to help clear debris from roads. In the aftermath of the storms, there has been a renewed focus on the need for improved infrastructure and disaster preparedness. California Governor Gavin Newsom has called for increased investment in flood control measures, such as levees and stormwater management systems. He has also emphasized the importance of addressing climate change, which is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events. The scientific community has been closely monitoring the atmospheric rivers and their impact on California. Researchers at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography have been using satellite data and weather models to track the storms and to predict their potential impact. This information has been crucial in helping authorities to prepare for and respond to the storms. One of the key challenges in dealing with atmospheric rivers is the unpredictability of their behavior. While meteorologists can forecast the general path and intensity of these storms, there is still a great deal of uncertainty about their exact impact. This makes it difficult to plan and implement effective response measures. Despite these challenges, there have been some positive developments in the field of atmospheric river research. Advances in remote sensing technology have improved the ability to monitor these storms in real-time. Additionally, new weather models are providing more accurate predictions of their behavior. These tools are helping to improve the accuracy of forecasts and to enhance the ability of authorities to respond to these events. Public awareness and education are also important components of disaster preparedness. In California, efforts have been made to educate residents about the risks associated with atmospheric rivers and to provide information on how to stay safe during these events. This includes advice on creating emergency kits, developing evacuation plans, and staying informed about weather conditions. The recent atmospheric rivers have also highlighted the importance of community resilience. In many areas, neighbors have come together to support one another, sharing resources and providing assistance to those in need. This sense of community has been a crucial factor in helping people to cope with the impact of the storms. Looking ahead, it is clear that atmospheric rivers will continue to pose a significant threat to California. Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of these storms, making it more important than ever to invest in infrastructure and preparedness measures. By improving our understanding of these events and by taking proactive steps to mitigate their impact, we can help to protect communities and to reduce the damage caused by future storms. In conclusion, the recent atmospheric rivers have had a profound impact on California, causing widespread flooding, power outages, and economic losses. The response to these storms has involved a coordinated effort from multiple agencies, with a focus on providing assistance to affected communities and on improving disaster preparedness. As climate change continues to influence weather patterns, it is essential to invest in infrastructure and to enhance our understanding of atmospheric rivers. By doing so, we can help to mitigate the impact of these events and to build more resilient communities.
Economy: On July 26, 2024, Prime Minister Narendra Modi virtually inaugurated the construction of the Shinkun La Tunnel, which is set to become the world’s highest tunnel. This tunnel is located in the Kargil district of Ladakh, India, at an impressive altitude of approximately 15,800 feet. The Shinkun La Tunnel is a significant infrastructure project that promises to enhance connectivity and boost economic development in the region. The Shinkun La Tunnel is part of the Nimu-Padum-Darcha Road, a crucial route that aims to improve access in the rugged terrain of Ladakh. The tunnel itself will be 4.1 kilometers long and will feature a twin-tube structure. This design is intended to ensure safety and efficiency in the movement of vehicles through the tunnel. The project has a budget of INR 1,681 crore, which was approved by the Prime Minister-led Cabinet Committee on Security in February 2023. The construction of the tunnel is being undertaken by the Border Roads Organisation (BRO), which has a long history of building strategic roads and tunnels in challenging environments. One of the key benefits of the Shinkun La Tunnel is its potential to enhance the movement of armed forces and equipment. Given the ongoing military tensions in eastern Ladakh, the tunnel will play a critical role in troop mobilization and the movement of heavy weapons along the northern borders with China. This is particularly important for maintaining India’s defense capabilities in the region. In addition to its strategic importance, the Shinkun La Tunnel is expected to bring significant economic benefits to both Ladakh and Himachal Pradesh. The improved connectivity will facilitate trade and tourism, providing new opportunities for local businesses and communities. The tunnel will also make it easier for residents to access essential services, such as healthcare and education, which are often difficult to reach due to the harsh weather conditions in the region. The Shinkun La Tunnel will feature cross-passages every 500 meters, which will enhance safety by providing emergency exits in case of accidents or other incidents. The project is projected to be completed within two years, with an expected completion date in mid-2026. The inauguration of the Shinkun La Tunnel marks a significant milestone in India’s infrastructure development. It follows the successful completion of the Atal Tunnel in Himachal Pradesh, which was inaugurated by Prime Minister Modi in October 2020. The Atal Tunnel, which is the world’s longest highway tunnel, has already brought substantial benefits to the region by improving connectivity and reducing travel time. The Shinkun La Tunnel is expected to have a similar impact, transforming the lives of people in Ladakh and beyond. The tunnel will reduce the distance between Manali and Leh by 60 kilometers, making travel more convenient and efficient. This will be particularly beneficial for tourists, who will be able to explore the stunning landscapes of Ladakh with greater ease. The construction of the Shinkun La Tunnel is a remarkable engineering feat, given the challenging conditions in which it is being built. The high altitude, extreme weather, and rugged terrain present significant obstacles that require innovative solutions and advanced technology. The BRO has a proven track record of overcoming such challenges, and the Shinkun La Tunnel is expected to be another testament to their expertise and dedication. The project has also generated a sense of pride and excitement among the local population. The people of Ladakh have long faced difficulties due to the region’s remote location and harsh climate. The Shinkun La Tunnel represents a new era of development and progress, offering hope for a brighter future. In conclusion, the inauguration of the Shinkun La Tunnel is a landmark event that underscores India’s commitment to enhancing connectivity and infrastructure in its border regions. The tunnel’s strategic and economic benefits will have a lasting impact on Ladakh and the surrounding areas, contributing to the region’s growth and prosperity. As the world’s highest tunnel, the Shinkun La Tunnel is a symbol of India’s engineering prowess and determination to overcome challenges in pursuit of progress.

On September 18, 2024, the Union Cabinet, chaired by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, approved the continuation of the Pradhan Mantri Annadata Aay Sanrakshan Abhiyan (PM-AASHA) scheme. This decision aims to provide better prices to farmers and control price volatility of essential commodities for consumers. The scheme has been allocated a substantial budget of INR 35,000 crore for the 15th Finance Commission Cycle, which extends up to 2025-26. PM-AASHA is an integrated scheme that includes several components designed to support farmers. These components are the Price Support Scheme (PSS), the Price Stabilization Fund (PSF), the Price Deficit Payment Scheme (PDPS), and the Market Intervention Scheme (MIS). Each of these components plays a crucial role in ensuring that farmers receive remunerative prices for their produce and that consumers have access to essential commodities at affordable prices. The Price Support Scheme (PSS) involves the procurement of notified pulses, oilseeds, and copra at the Minimum Support Price (MSP). From the 2024-25 season onwards, the procurement under PSS will cover 25% of the national production of these crops. This will enable states to procure more of these crops at MSP, ensuring remunerative prices for farmers and preventing distress sales. However, for the 2024-25 season, there will be 100% procurement of Tur, Urad, and Masur, as previously decided. The Price Stabilization Fund (PSF) is designed to protect consumers from extreme price volatility in agri-horticultural commodities. The PSF will maintain a strategic buffer stock of pulses and onions, which can be released in a calibrated manner to discourage hoarding and unscrupulous speculation. This buffer stock will help ensure that consumers have access to these essential commodities at stable and affordable prices. The Price Deficit Payment Scheme (PDPS) aims to bridge the gap between the MSP and the actual market price of notified crops. Under this scheme, farmers will receive direct payments to compensate for any shortfall in market prices below the MSP. This ensures that farmers are protected from price fluctuations and receive a fair return for their produce. The Market Intervention Scheme (MIS) is another critical component of PM-AASHA. It is designed to intervene in the market when prices of perishable and horticultural commodities fall below a certain level. The MIS helps stabilize prices by procuring these commodities from farmers and ensuring their availability in the market at reasonable prices. The continuation of PM-AASHA also includes a renewed and enhanced government guarantee of INR 45,000 crore for the procurement of notified pulses, oilseeds, and copra at MSP. This guarantee will facilitate more procurement by the Department of Agriculture and Farmers Welfare (DA&FW) from farmers, including pre-registered farmers on the eSamridhi portal of the National Agricultural Cooperative Marketing Federation of India (NAFED) and the eSamyukti portal of the National Cooperative Consumers’ Federation of India (NCCF). This initiative will motivate farmers to cultivate more of these crops, contributing to self-sufficiency and reducing dependence on imports. The extension of the PSF scheme will also help in protecting consumers from extreme price volatility in agri-horticultural commodities. By maintaining a strategic buffer stock of pulses and onions, the government can release these commodities in a calibrated manner to discourage hoarding and unscrupulous speculation. This will ensure that consumers have access to these essential commodities at stable and affordable prices. The procurement of pulses at market price will be done by the Department of Consumer Affairs (DoCA), including pre-registered farmers on the eSamridhi portal of NAFED and the eSamyukti portal of NCCF whenever prices rule above MSP in the market. This initiative will help in stabilizing prices and ensuring that consumers have access to essential commodities at reasonable prices. The continuation of PM-AASHA is expected to bring significant benefits to farmers and consumers alike. By providing remunerative prices to farmers, the scheme will help in improving their income and livelihood. This, in turn, will encourage farmers to invest in better farming practices and technologies, leading to increased agricultural productivity and sustainability. For consumers, the scheme will help in controlling price volatility and ensuring the availability of essential commodities at affordable prices. This is particularly important in a country like India, where a large proportion of the population depends on agriculture for their livelihood and food security. The approval of the continuation of PM-AASHA is a testament to the government’s commitment to supporting farmers and ensuring food security for the nation. The scheme is expected to play a crucial role in achieving the government’s goal of doubling farmers’ income by 2022, as envisioned by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. In conclusion, the Union Cabinet’s approval of the continuation of PM-AASHA is a significant step towards providing better prices to farmers and controlling price volatility of essential commodities for consumers. With a budget of INR 35,000 crore and a renewed government guarantee of INR 45,000 crore, the scheme is well-equipped to achieve its objectives. The integrated approach of PM-AASHA, with its various components, will ensure that farmers receive remunerative prices for their produce and that consumers have access to essential commodities at stable and affordable prices. This will contribute to the overall growth and development of the agricultural sector and ensure food security for the nation.

On September 18, 2024, the Union Cabinet, chaired by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, approved the Nutrient Based Subsidy (NBS) rates for Phosphatic and Potassic (P&K) fertilizers for the Rabi season. This decision is crucial for ensuring the availability of fertilizers to farmers at subsidized and affordable prices. The approved subsidy rates are aimed at stabilizing the prices of fertilizers and supporting the agricultural sector during the Rabi season, which spans from October 1, 2024, to March 31, 2025. The Nutrient Based Subsidy (NBS) scheme was introduced by the Government of India on April 1, 2010. Under this scheme, the subsidy on fertilizers is provided based on the nutrient content of the fertilizers, rather than the type of fertilizer. This approach ensures that farmers receive subsidies for the essential nutrients required for crop growth, such as Nitrogen (N), Phosphorus (P), Potash (K), and Sulphur (S). For the Rabi season of 2024-25, the approved subsidy rates per kilogram are as follows: Nitrogen (N) at INR 47.2, Phosphorus (P) at INR 20.82, Potash (K) at INR 2.38, and Sulphur (S) at INR 1.89. These rates are designed to offset the cost of fertilizers for farmers, making them more affordable and accessible. The total budgetary allocation for the NBS scheme for the Rabi season of 2024-25 is approximately INR 24,475.53 crore. This substantial financial outlay underscores the government’s commitment to supporting the agricultural sector and ensuring food security for the nation. The subsidy will be provided to fertilizer companies based on the approved rates, enabling them to supply fertilizers to farmers at the subsidized prices. One of the primary objectives of the NBS scheme is to ensure the availability of fertilizers to farmers at reasonable prices, despite fluctuations in international market prices. The government absorbs the volatility in the prices of fertilizers and raw materials, ensuring that farmers are not burdened with high costs. This is particularly important given the recent trends in the international prices of fertilizers and inputs such as Urea, Di-Ammonium Phosphate (DAP), Muriate of Potash (MOP), and Sulphur. The NBS scheme covers 28 grades of Phosphatic and Potassic (P&K) fertilizers, which are made available to farmers through fertilizer manufacturers and importers. The scheme also includes a provision for a freight subsidy to support the transportation of Single Super Phosphate (SSP) fertilizers, further reducing the cost burden on farmers. The approval of the NBS rates for the Rabi season is expected to have several positive impacts on the agricultural sector. Firstly, it will ensure the timely availability of fertilizers to farmers, enabling them to plan and execute their farming activities efficiently. This is crucial for the Rabi season, which is a significant cropping season in India, with major crops such as wheat, barley, mustard, and gram being cultivated. Secondly, the subsidy will help in maintaining soil fertility by encouraging the balanced use of fertilizers. By providing subsidies based on the nutrient content, the NBS scheme promotes the use of a balanced mix of nutrients, which is essential for sustainable agricultural practices. This, in turn, will lead to improved crop yields and better quality produce. Thirdly, the NBS scheme will contribute to the overall economic well-being of farmers by reducing their input costs. Lower fertilizer prices mean that farmers can invest more in other aspects of farming, such as high-quality seeds, irrigation, and farm machinery. This will enhance their productivity and profitability, contributing to the goal of doubling farmers’ income by 2022, as envisioned by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The implementation of the NBS scheme involves a robust monitoring and evaluation mechanism to ensure that the subsidies reach the intended beneficiaries. The Department of Fertilizers, in collaboration with state governments and fertilizer companies, oversees the distribution and utilization of fertilizers. This includes regular inspections, audits, and the use of technology to track the movement of fertilizers from manufacturers to farmers. In addition to the NBS scheme, the government has also implemented several other initiatives to support the agricultural sector. These include the Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi (PM-KISAN) scheme, which provides direct income support to farmers, and the Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana (PMFBY), which offers crop insurance to protect farmers against losses due to natural calamities. The continuation of the NBS scheme and the approval of the subsidy rates for the Rabi season reflect the government’s commitment to the welfare of farmers and the agricultural sector. By ensuring the availability of affordable fertilizers, the scheme plays a crucial role in enhancing agricultural productivity and sustainability. The approval of the NBS rates for the Rabi season also highlights the importance of a collaborative approach in addressing the challenges faced by the agricultural sector. The government, fertilizer companies, and farmers must work together to ensure the effective implementation of the scheme and the timely availability of fertilizers. This collaboration is essential for achieving the broader goals of food security, economic growth, and rural development. In conclusion, the Union Cabinet’s approval of the Nutrient Based Subsidy (NBS) rates for Phosphatic and Potassic (P&K) fertilizers for the Rabi season is a significant step towards supporting the agricultural sector and ensuring food security for the nation. With a budgetary allocation of INR 24,475.53 crore and approved subsidy rates for essential nutrients, the NBS scheme will provide much-needed relief to farmers and promote sustainable agricultural practices. The scheme’s impact on soil fertility, crop yields, and farmers’ economic well-being underscores its importance in the overall development of the agricultural sector. As the Rabi season approaches, the timely implementation of the NBS scheme will be crucial in ensuring that farmers have access to affordable fertilizers and can carry out their farming activities efficiently.

National High-Speed Road Corridors The development of National High-Speed Road Corridors in India marks a significant milestone in the country’s infrastructure growth. These corridors aim to enhance connectivity, reduce travel time, and boost economic activities across various regions. The Union Cabinet recently approved eight major National High-Speed Road Corridor projects, spanning a total length of 936 kilometers, with an estimated investment of Rs. 50,655 crore. These projects are expected to generate approximately 4.42 crore mandays of direct and indirect employment. One of the key projects is the 6-lane Agra-Gwalior National High-Speed Corridor. This 88-kilometer stretch will be developed on a Build-Operate-Transfer (BOT) basis, with a total capital cost of Rs. 4,613 crore. The corridor will supplement the existing 4-lane National Highway, increasing traffic capacity by more than two times. It will enhance connectivity to key tourist destinations such as the Taj Mahal in Uttar Pradesh and the Gwalior Fort in Madhya Pradesh. The project is expected to reduce the distance between Agra and Gwalior by 7% and cut travel time by 50%, significantly lowering logistics costs. Another important project is the 4-lane Kharagpur-Moregram National High-Speed Corridor. This 231-kilometer corridor will be developed in Hybrid Annuity Mode (HAM) at a total capital cost of Rs. 10,247 crore. The new corridor will increase traffic capacity by about five times, providing efficient connectivity between states like West Bengal, Odisha, and Andhra Pradesh on one end and the North-Eastern part of the country on the other. This project is expected to transform the economy of West Bengal and the North-East by improving logistics efficiency and reducing congestion. The 6-lane Tharad-Deesa-Mehsana-Ahmedabad National High-Speed Corridor is another significant project. This corridor will complete the high-speed road network in Gujarat, ensuring seamless port connectivity and reducing logistics costs. The project will span a total length of 200 kilometers and will be developed at a capital cost of Rs. 8,500 crore. It will enhance connectivity between key industrial hubs and ports, facilitating the movement of goods and boosting economic activities in the region. The 4-lane Ayodhya Ring Road is also part of the approved projects. This 50-kilometer corridor will be developed at a total capital cost of Rs. 2,500 crore. The project aims to decongest the existing road network around Ayodhya, providing faster and more efficient connectivity to the city. It will also enhance access to the upcoming Ram Temple, which is expected to attract millions of tourists annually. The Raipur-Ranchi National High-Speed Corridor includes a 4-lane section between Pathalgaon and Gumla. This 150-kilometer stretch will be developed at a total capital cost of Rs. 6,000 crore. The project will unlock the growth potential of Jharkhand and Chhattisgarh by improving connectivity between the two states. It will also facilitate the movement of goods and people, boosting economic activities in the region. The 6-lane Kanpur Ring Road is another crucial project. This 100-kilometer corridor will be developed at a total capital cost of Rs. 5,000 crore. The project aims to decongest the existing road network around Kanpur, providing faster and more efficient connectivity to the city. It will also enhance access to key industrial areas, facilitating the movement of goods and boosting economic activities in the region. The Tharad-Ahmedabad corridor will span a total length of 200 kilometers and will be developed at a capital cost of Rs. 8,500 crore. This project will complete the high-speed road network in Gujarat, ensuring seamless port connectivity and reducing logistics costs. It will enhance connectivity between key industrial hubs and ports, facilitating the movement of goods and boosting economic activities in the region. The Guwahati Ring Road is another significant project. This 117-kilometer corridor will be developed at a total capital cost of Rs. 5,795 crore. The project aims to decongest the existing road network around Guwahati, providing faster and more efficient connectivity to the city. It will also enhance access to the North-Eastern part of the country, facilitating the movement of goods and people and boosting economic activities in the region. The implementation of these National High-Speed Road Corridor projects is expected to bring numerous benefits. Firstly, they will significantly reduce travel time between major cities and industrial hubs, enhancing logistics efficiency and reducing transportation costs. For instance, the Agra-Gwalior corridor is expected to cut travel time by 50%, while the Kharagpur-Moregram corridor will increase traffic capacity by about five times. Secondly, these projects will boost economic activities by improving connectivity between key industrial areas and ports. The Tharad-Deesa-Mehsana-Ahmedabad corridor, for example, will enhance connectivity between key industrial hubs and ports in Gujarat, facilitating the movement of goods and boosting economic activities in the region. Similarly, the Raipur-Ranchi corridor will unlock the growth potential of Jharkhand and Chhattisgarh by improving connectivity between the two states. Thirdly, the projects will generate significant employment opportunities. The implementation of these eight projects is expected to generate approximately 4.42 crore mandays of direct and indirect employment. This will provide a much-needed boost to the economy, particularly in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, which has led to widespread job losses and economic slowdown. In addition to these benefits, the National High-Speed Road Corridors will also enhance connectivity to key tourist destinations, boosting tourism and related economic activities. The Agra-Gwalior corridor, for instance, will enhance connectivity to the Taj Mahal and the Gwalior Fort, attracting more tourists to these iconic landmarks. Similarly, the Ayodhya Ring Road will enhance access to the upcoming Ram Temple, which is expected to attract millions of tourists annually. The development of National High-Speed Road Corridors is a crucial step towards building a robust and efficient transportation network in India. These projects will not only enhance connectivity and reduce travel time but also boost economic activities and generate significant employment opportunities. As the country continues to recover from the economic impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, the implementation of these projects will provide a much-needed boost to the economy, paving the way for sustained growth and development in the years to come.

RBI Shifted 100 Tonnes Gold Back to India from UK In a significant move, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has recently shifted over 100 tonnes of gold from the United Kingdom to its domestic vaults. This marks the first time since 1991 that such a substantial quantity of gold has been repatriated to India. The decision to bring back the gold is driven by logistical considerations and a desire for diversified storage, reflecting the RBI’s evolving approach to managing its gold reserves. As of the end of March 2024, the RBI held 822.10 tonnes of gold, with 408.31 tonnes stored domestically. The recent transfer adds to the domestically held reserves, indicating a potential increase in the gold stored within India. This move is expected to save on storage fees paid to foreign custodians, such as the Bank of England, and indicates confidence in the Indian economy’s stability. The share of gold in the total foreign exchange reserves rose to 8.7% by the end of April 2024. This increase is significant as central banks globally have been increasing their gold holdings amid economic uncertainties. The RBI’s actions reflect a broader trend and signal confidence in India’s economic stability. The RBI has a history of purchasing gold. It started buying gold in 2018 and had previously bought 200 tonnes during the global financial crisis in 2009. In the first quarter of 2024, the RBI bought 19 tonnes of gold, surpassing the 16 tonnes purchased throughout 2023. This steady accumulation of gold stocks highlights the central bank’s strategic approach to managing its foreign exchange reserves. The decision to move the gold back to India is also influenced by logistical reasons. The transfer helps in saving on storage fees paid to foreign custodians and ensures diversified storage. The RBI’s objective of holding gold in reserves is mainly to diversify its foreign currency assets base, as a hedge against inflation and foreign currency risks. The RBI’s gold reserves are stored in vaults in Mumbai and Nagpur. According to a World Gold Council report, global central banks own about 17% of all the gold ever mined, with reserves topping 36,699 metric tons as of year-end 2023. They acquired the vast majority in the last 14 years after becoming net buyers of the metal in 2010. The move to repatriate gold is not unique to India.
